importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed on October 9, 2025, setting the timeline for the return of deceased hostages.
The transfer of two coffins containing deceased hostages into Israel occurred on October 21, 2025, marking the 14th and 15th confirmed deceased hostages to be returned under the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Under the Trump administration’s ceasefire agreement, Hamas was supposed to return all deceased hostages within the first 72 hours of the ceasefire going into effect.

keyTakeAways: Two coffins carrying the remains of deceased Israeli hostages have been transferred into Israel by Hamas, escorted by Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) troops, following the ceasefire agreement.

The bodies are being processed at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification; if confirmed, they will be the 14th and 15th deceased hostages to be returned since the October 9 ceasefire.
Hamas has reportedly faced challenges in locating and recovering all bodies due to war damage, including rubble, and one previously returned body was misidentified.
The US Vice President, JD Vance, affirmed that the return of bodies is a priority, but emphasized it is not going to happen overnight and some bodies are buried under rubble.
The ceasefire agreement has been called into question due to disputes over compliance—Israel accused Hamas of violating the agreement, and Hamas accused Israel of attacks that killed two soldiers.
The US administration has not set a timeline for full disarmament or return of all deceased hostages, only stressed the humanitarian imperative of recovering remains.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel is the state receiving the coffins and is central to the narrative of the hostage situation, ceasefire, and military enforcement of the agreement.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is the group responsible for holding hostages and is required under the ceasefire agreement to return deceased hostage remains to Israel.

namedEntities.name: Al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Al-Qassam Brigades confirmed the scheduled transfer of hostage bodies and are directly involved in the recovery and transfer process in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF is responsible for receiving, escorting, and processing the coffins into Israel and managing public messaging about the transfer.

namedEntities.name: Israel Security Agency (ISA)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ISA, in coordination with the IDF, confirmed the transfer and is involved in assessing Hamas’s compliance with the ceasefire terms.

namedEntities.name: Red Cross
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Red Cross facilitated the handover of the coffins from Gaza to Israeli authorities, indicating the role of neutral humanitarian actors in conflict zones.

namedEntities.name: US Vice President JD Vance
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance visited Israel to support the ceasefire and downplayed concerns about its stability, emphasizing the urgency and difficulty of recovering bodies.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration proposed and supported the ceasefire deal, which sets the terms for hostage return and ceasefire enforcement.

namedEntities.name: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is one of the 13 formally identified deceased hostages returned under the ceasefire agreement, establishing a human face to the humanitarian crisis.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The site where the bodies are being examined and identified, central to the verification and confirmation process of the deceased hostages.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two coffins containing the remains of deceased Israeli hostages have crossed into Israel from Gaza, escorted by Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) and handed over by Hamas, following the October 9 ceasefire agreement. The bodies are being processed at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification, marking the 14th and 15th confirmed deceased hostages to be returned. Hamas has faced difficulties in recovering all bodies due to war damage and previous misidentification of one body. The Israeli military and security agencies stress that the return of all bodies is essential for closure and humanitarian reasons, while the US Vice President JD Vance emphasized the difficulty and timeline challenges, noting that some bodies are buried under rubble. Tensions remain between Israel and Hamas over compliance with the ceasefire, with accusations of violations on both sides. This is a developing story tied to broader geopolitical and humanitarian concerns over peace, accountability, and the recovery of victims in a war-torn region.
title: Israeli Military Says Two Coffins Said to Contain Hostages’ Bodies Cross Into Israel
